title: Trump says big cities are much more dangerous than the suburbs. Is that true in Northeast Ohio?
description: President Donald Trump is using crime rates as a reason to deploy federal troops to major, U.S. cities. What are crime rates for cities, townships and villages in Northeast Ohio?
content:
How do Cleveland's crime rates compare to those of the suburbs? Cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer examined FBI data, given President Donald Trump's rationale for sending the military to cities. Rich Exner, cleveland.com

CLEVELAND, Ohio – President Donald Trump’s threats to send troops to U.S. cities have rekindled the issues of crime and the disparities facing urban communities and their outlying neighbors.

And while experts say crime has dropped in the past several years, fears of it have persisted.

In Cleveland, the gap in crime rates between the city and its suburbs remained wide last year, as the city leads the region in the rate of violent crime.

The disparity between Cleveland and the suburbs is most striking in cities like Middlefield in Geauga County, Mantua in Portage and Olmsted Falls in Cuyahoga, where police reported no violent crime last year.

To determine the differences between large cities and their suburbs in the region’s eight counties, Cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer used FBI and census data to analyze the crime rates for 123 cities, villages and townships.

The analysis comes in the wake of Trump’s takeover of Washington, D.C., by the National Guard and his deployment of troops to Los Angeles earlier this year. In recent weeks, the president has threatened to deploy soldiers to other U.S. cities such as Chicago, Baltimore, San Francisco and New York, arguing crime rates necessitate such action.

The data and crime experts provide a more nuanced view of crime than the president’s narrative suggests, that crime is out of control.

Cleveland city officials often note their crime rates are down since the pandemic, a figure that is reflected in data from both the FBI and the office of the Cuyahoga County medical examiner. That mirrors national trends.

“Public safety has been and always will be our No. 1 priority,” Cleveland spokesman Tyler Sinclair said in a statement. “We will continue to aggressively combat crime wherever it happens and whenever it happens, and will work to apprehend whoever is responsible.”

Cleveland’s violent crime rate was followed by East Cleveland and then Akron, data shows.

Rates of property crimes were perhaps more unexpected. For example, the suburb of Brooklyn reported a higher property crime rate than Cleveland last year. Springfield Township, a Summit County suburb, had a higher property crime rate than Akron last year.

Small numbers tend to skew percentages, and that’s true with crime data as well. Cuyahoga Heights, a town of 556 people, reported four violent crimes in 2024, giving it – at least on paper – a violent crime rate that’s higher than Lorain, Garfield Heights or Elyria.

Experts also caution against apples-to-oranges comparisons between towns. For example, most suburbs in Northeast Ohio don’t have as many retail stores as Beachwood and Strongsville, meaning there are simply fewer opportunities to steal at many other communities.

Not only do crime rates differ between the city and the suburbs, residents in the two areas also have a different relationship with law enforcement, said Lew Katz, a former chairman of the Cleveland Community Police Commission.

“We were trying to get police to react the same to everyone,” said Katz, who is a professor emeritus of law at Case Western Reserve University. “That doesn’t exist, and that’s a tragedy.”

Crime rates for communities are useful, albeit imperfect data, said Daniel Flannery, the director of the Begun Center for Violence Prevention Research and Education at Case Western Reserve University.

One of the key reasons why crime data can be flawed is that reporting is optional, and there are many discrepancies between how one department reports its crime rates compared to another.

Many small departments don’t report their crime rates to the FBI. In cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer’s analysis of local crime rates, the newspaper identified 67 local governments that did not report crime rates.

For many of those, no figures exist because they were small enough to contract with a county sheriff or an adjacent town for their policing services.

Some mid-size suburbs, such as Shaker Heights and Middleburg Heights, also did not submit 2024 crime data to the FBI.

Crime rates are falling, generally, across the country, particularly after a post-COVID-19 spike in crime across the board.

A July report from the Council on Criminal Justice looked at data for 30 U.S. cities and found homicides were down 17% compared to last year. Aggravated assaults, gun assaults, sexual assaults and robberies were also down, the report said.

However, many people feel unsafe in their neighborhoods.

“You may not feel as safe walking around Shaker Square because the lighting needs to be improved,” Flannery said. “It doesn’t mean it’s a violent neighborhood.”

Despite the flaws in crime data, Katz thinks they are largely telling the correct story: that crime is down overall. But personal experiences are far more likely to affect someone’s perception of safety than statistics.

“I think the statistics are accurate,” Katz said. “(But) if you’re a victim, crime isn’t down.”

One program Katz thought was particularly successful in reducing crime was “Hoops After Dark,” which provides positive activities for people in neighborhoods disproportionately affected by crime.

“We need to be doing more about providing activities to kids and young adults to do in their free time,” Katz said.

With some of these programs in the crosshairs of federal budget cuts, Flannery worries much of that progress could be undone.

“It’s not a long-term effective strategy, in my view, to just send in the military to an entire city every time the perception is – or the rhetoric is – that this is a violent community that’s completely out of control," Flannery said. “That’s not a sustainable model.”

For cities, townships and villages in Ashtabula, Cuyahoga, Geauga, Lake, Lorain, Medina, Portage and Summit counties that reported crimes to the FBI in 2024, here is how their crime rates compared to their populations.

Violent crime includes homicide, rape, robbery and aggravated assault. Property crime includes arson, burglary, theft and motor vehicle theft, according to the FBI’s website.
summary: Cleveland's crime rates have been compared to those of the suburbs, given President Donald Trump's claim that big cities are more dangerous than the suburbs. The study was conducted by Cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer in response to the president's claims that crime rates in large U.S. cities such as Chicago, Baltimore, San Francisco, and New York are higher than those in the suburbs due to higher property crime rates. The disparity is most noticeable in cities like Middlefield in Geauga County, Mantua in Portage and Olmsted Falls in Cuyahoga. Cleveland.gov and The newspaper's analysis also found that crime in the city has decreased since the pandemic of the last decade, mirroring national trends. However, experts caution against apples-to-oranges comparisons between towns.
shortSummary: President Donald Trump's recent threats of military intervention in American cities highlight regional crime disparities, particularly in Cleveland.

CLEVELAND, Ohio – As Cleveland enters its most deadly months of the year, at least two local violence prevention groups are reducing services because of federal budget cuts.
Leaders from the Brenda Glass Trauma Recovery Center and Cleveland Peacemakers Alliance told cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer they have already cut staff or services after President Donald Trump’s administration canceled $1.7 million in remaining grant funding.
Though the cuts were announced in April, the nonprofits are seeing the effects play out now, as gun violence begins its seasonal increase and the groups’ services are most needed.
That was highlighted earlier this week, when suspects fired 80 gunshots at a block party during an East Side shootout that left one dead and five injured.
That attack followed one earlier this month, when seven people were injured in a mass shooting in Cleveland’s Lee-Harvard neighborhood.
“We’re praying we’re able to find some funds for June because we don’t want to stop helping people who aren’t safe,” said Brenda Glass, the center’s founder and CEO.
As a result, Glass has cut three staff members and may have to close some of the 12 safe houses meant for witnesses or victims of violent crime, she said. In 2023, the nonprofit had eight staff members.
The Peacemakers Alliance, perhaps best known for fighting youth violence and working in hospitals to prevent retaliatory shootings, has cut wraparound services such as helping crime victims with utility support, funeral expenses, housing, recouping lost wages and food, said Myesha Watkins, the executive director.
“It puts us in a position where we can only offer thoughts and prayers,” Watkins said of the budget cuts.
For now, the group can afford to pay outreach workers in hospitals, Watkins said. To do so, the nonprofit is pulling from its general fund, which it cannot do indefinitely, she said.
The Peacemakers Alliance gained the $2 million grant through the U.S. Justice Department. It then distributed $832,000 to Glass for the trauma center and $350,000 to Cleveland State University for research.
The trauma center had already spent $310,592 from the grant and Cleveland State had spent roughly $70,000, officials from those groups said.
The rest was supposed to last until September 2026. The financial loss is a substantial hit to the agencies, and it appears to be their largest source of funding. In the most recent available tax documents, the agencies each brought in less than $600,000 in 2023.
For the trauma center, the laid-off staff include a part-time therapist, a part-time housing coordinator and a full-time case manager, said Glass, who took a 50% pay cut in addition to the layoffs.
Most recently, the Peacemakers Alliance secured a $75,000 grant, a third of which will go to the Brenda Glass center, from the national nonprofit Community Based Public Safety Collective.
While some local organizations like the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Cleveland Foundation have been generous with their support, Watkins said, “There’s no organization investing the amount that was lost.”
These programs do more than just comfort the victims of crime.
Since the trauma center also helps willing witnesses testify by giving them safe housing and transportation to court, the program “not only cleans up the streets but helps people willing to testify get the safety they need, which they’re not going to get from the justice system,” Glass said.
One of the program’s current clients, who asked cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer not to publish his name because of his fear of reprisals, said the Brenda Glass Trauma Recovery Center has been key to getting him to leave a dangerous situation.
After spending a week in the hospital for a gunshot wound, the trauma center moved him into a hotel for a week with his girlfriend before they ended up in a safe house, he said.
From there, the center helped him with big things like transportation and therapy, but it also little things like kitchenware and groceries, he said.
“The little things for sure added up because I needed (them),” he said.
For him, the trauma recovery center represented “a better opportunity” than where he was living. And unlike some shelter programs, he was able to enter the program with his girlfriend, as a unit.
“They seemed like a safe environment to go to,” he said. “They say they’ll do something, and they do it. So, I just trusted them.”
Even when they leave the safety of the agency, the trauma center’s clients often take that opportunity to improve their lives, she said.
“Ninety-five percent of the people we serve decide they want to do something better,” Glass said. “They don’t want to stay in these neighborhoods where violence is happening daily.”
Glass’ program has helped 163 people since last July. The grant cancellation blocked $280,000 from funding research on the program’s effectiveness through Cleveland State University.
Rachel Lovell, an assistant professor of criminology who was working on the research, said the canceled funding will have a “profound” effect on Cleveland’s gun violence victims.
“The trauma that people experience either firsthand or secondhand from gun violence lasts generations,” Lovell said.
“Being able to address that when it happens is extremely important to be able for communities to heal and for victims and their families to heal.”

argos_summary: Cleveland’s violent crime rate remains markedly higher than that of its suburbs, a gap highlighted by FBI and census data used by Cleveland.com and The Plain Dealer amid President Trump’s rhetoric about deploying troops to cities.  While overall U.S. crime has fallen—homicides down 17% last year—Cleveland officials note a post‑pandemic decline that is still eclipsed by suburban rates.  Local violence‑prevention groups, such as the Brenda Glass Trauma Recovery Center and Cleveland Peacemakers Alliance, have cut staff and services after the Trump administration cancelled $1.7 million in federal grant funding, jeopardizing programs that support victims and witnesses.  The article underscores the tension between national policy narratives and the nuanced, data‑driven reality of crime trends in the region.
